question:
Identify the function of lipase in the process of digestion.

SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (1st shift)
solution:
• Lipase is an enzyme that plays a crucial role in the digestion of fats.
  • It specifically acts on emulsified fats, breaking them down into fatty acids and glycerol.
  • Emulsification of fats (done by bile salts) increases the surface area for lipase to act efficiently.
  • Lipase is secreted by:
    • Pancreas (main source)
    • Salivary glands (in minor amounts)
    • Stomach (gastric lipase)
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Breaking down roughage – done by bacterial action in large intestine, not by lipase
    • (c) Secreting intestinal fluids – is a function of intestinal glands
    • (d) Digesting proteins – done by enzymes like pepsin and trypsin, not lipase

Additional Information:

  • Lipase functions best in an alkaline environment, provided by the pancreas and bile in the small intestine.
  • It is essential for absorbing fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K).

question:
Which of the following statements is NOT correct regarding the liver?

SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (3rd shift)
option_1: It is situated in the upper part of the abdomen on the left side
option_2: It secretes bile juice that is stored in a sac called the gallbladder
option_3: It is the largest gland in the body
option_4: It is a reddish-brown gland
solution:
• The liver is the largest gland in the human body and plays a central role in digestion, metabolism, and detoxification.
  • Correct statements:
    • (b) It secretes bile juice, which is stored in the gallbladder – ✔️
    • (c) It is indeed the largest gland – ✔️
    • (d) It is reddish-brown due to its rich blood supply – ✔️
  • Incorrect statement:
    • (a) The liver is located in the upper right side of the abdomen, not the left side – ❌

Additional Information:

  • The liver performs many functions such as:
    • Detoxifying chemicals
    • Metabolizing drugs
    • Storing glycogen, vitamins, and minerals
    • Producing proteins important for blood clotting

question:
Liver gland secretes ________ that are stored in a sac called the gallbladder.

SSC MTS 13/06/2023 (Evening)
solution:
• The liver is a vital digestive gland that secretes bile juice, a yellow-green fluid.
  • Bile juice helps in the emulsification of fats, breaking them into smaller droplets to aid digestion by lipase.
  • Although bile is produced by the liver, it is stored and concentrated in the gallbladder, a small sac-like organ located beneath the liver.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Estrogen – A hormone produced by ovaries (in females), not by the liver
    • (b) Hydrochloric acid – Secreted by the stomach, not the liver
    • (c) Mucous – Secreted by goblet cells in the digestive tract, not by the liver

Additional Information:

  • Bile contains bile salts, bile pigments (like bilirubin), cholesterol, and water.
  • It does not contain enzymes, but it is essential for fat digestion and absorption.

question:
In Humans, the digestion of carbohydrates like starch, begins in which of the following parts?

SSC CHSL 14/03/2023 (2nd shift)
solution:
• In humans, the digestion of carbohydrates like starch begins in the buccal cavity (mouth).
  • This process is initiated by the enzyme salivary amylase (also called ptyalin), which is present in saliva.
  • Salivary amylase breaks down starch into maltose, a simpler sugar.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Rectum – Part of the large intestine; involved in storage of waste, not digestion
    • (b) Small Intestine – Major site for digestion and absorption, but carbohydrate digestion starts earlier
    • (c) Oesophagus – A passageway for food; no digestive enzymes act here

Additional Information:

  • The buccal cavity is also responsible for mechanical digestion through chewing (mastication).
  • Optimal pH for salivary amylase activity is around 7–7.0 (slightly acidic to neutral).

question:
In ruminants like cattle, bacteria present in ________ helps in digestion of cellulose.

SSC CHSL 17/03/2023 (4th shift)
solution:
• In ruminants (like cattle, sheep, goats), the rumen is the first chamber of their stomach and plays a key role in digesting cellulose.
  • The rumen contains symbiotic bacteria and protozoa that produce cellulase, an enzyme that breaks down cellulose into simpler compounds.
  • This process is called microbial fermentation, and it allows ruminants to utilize plant materials (like grass) as a major energy source.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (b) Oesophagus – Only transports food; no digestion occurs here
    • (c) Small intestine – Main site of nutrient absorption, not initial cellulose digestion
    • (d) Large intestine – Involved in water absorption and minor fermentation, but not the main site for cellulose digestion in ruminants

Additional Information:

  • Ruminants regurgitate food from the rumen to chew it again — a process called rumination or cud-chewing.
  • Other stomach chambers in ruminants: reticulum, omasum, and abomasum.

question:
Which of the following animals have a single opening in their digestive system that serves both as a mouth and an anus?

SSC CGL 01/12/2022 (4th shift)
solution:
• Platyhelminthes (flatworms) are simple, bilaterally symmetrical invertebrates with a single opening in their digestive system.
  • This single opening acts as both the mouth and the anus, meaning food enters and waste exits through the same opening.
  • Examples: Planaria, Tapeworms, Liver flukes
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Arachnids – A class of arthropods (like spiders, scorpions); they have a complete digestive tract with separate mouth and anus.
    • (b) Echinoderms – (like starfish, sea urchins); they also possess a complete digestive system.
    • (d) Arthropods – (like insects, crustaceans); also have separate mouth and anus.

Additional Information:

  • A digestive system with one opening is called an incomplete digestive system.
  • Organisms with two openings (mouth and anus) have a complete digestive system, allowing for more efficient digestion and nutrient absorption.

question:
Which food requires a longer small intestine to digest food?

SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (3rd shift)
solution:
• Grass is rich in cellulose, a complex carbohydrate that is difficult to digest.
  • Animals (like herbivores) that consume grass require a longer small intestine to allow more time and surface area for microbial fermentation and nutrient absorption.
  • The longer small intestine helps in the slow and efficient digestion of cellulose with the help of symbiotic bacteria.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Lamb, (b) Eggs, (d) Chicken – These are animal-based protein-rich foods, which are easier and quicker to digest compared to cellulose-rich plant food.

Additional Information:

  • Herbivores like cows, goats, and deer have long small intestines and often specialized stomachs (like rumen) to aid in cellulose digestion.
  • In contrast, carnivores and omnivores have shorter digestive tracts suited for protein and fat digestion.

question:
Which of the following is NOT a function of calcium in our body?

SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Evening)
option_1: It plays an important role in blood clotting
option_2: It helps the digestive system
option_3: It is associated with healthy bones and teeth
option_4: It helps muscles to contract
solution:
• Calcium is a vital mineral in the human body with several essential functions, including:
    • (a) Blood clotting – Calcium is required for the proper functioning of clotting factors in the blood.
    • (c) Bone and teeth health – Around 99% of the body’s calcium is stored in bones and teeth, providing structural strength.
    • (d) Muscle contraction – Calcium ions play a key role in triggering muscle contraction, including the heart muscle.
  • Incorrect statement:
    • (b) It helps the digestive system – While calcium is absorbed in the digestive system, it is not directly involved in aiding digestion. Hence, this is not a primary function of calcium.

Additional Information:

  • Calcium also supports nerve transmission, cell signaling, and hormone release.
  • Deficiency can lead to conditions like osteoporosis, muscle cramps, and abnormal blood clotting.

question:
Which of the following is able to regenerate our digestive system with good microbes that will neutralize the harmful ones?

Higher Secondary 05/08/2022 (2nd shift)
solution:
• Probiotics are live beneficial microorganisms, usually bacteria or yeasts, that help restore and maintain the natural balance of gut flora in our digestive system.
  • They work by:
    • Replenishing good microbes
    • Suppressing the growth of harmful bacteria
    • Improving digestion and immunity
  • Common sources of probiotics:
    • Curd (yogurt)
    • Fermented foods like kimchi, kefir, and sauerkraut
    • Probiotic supplements
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Antibiotics – Kill both good and bad bacteria; may disrupt gut flora
    • (b) Prosthetics – Artificial body parts; unrelated to microbes or digestion
    • (d) Prosynthetics – Not a recognized biological term

Additional Information:

  • Probiotics are especially useful after antibiotic treatment, which can disturb gut microbiota.
  • They can help prevent diarrhea, constipation, and certain gut infections.

question:
Where are villi present in the human alimentary canal?

SSC MTS 07/07/2022 (1st shift)
solution:
• Villi are small, finger-like projections found in the inner lining of the small intestine.
  • Their main function is to increase the surface area for absorption of nutrients from digested food.
  • Each villus contains:
    • Blood capillaries – to absorb glucose and amino acids
    • Lacteals (lymph vessels) – to absorb fatty acids and glycerol
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Pancreas – Secretes digestive enzymes and hormones; no villi
    • (b) Oesophagus – Only transports food; no absorption
    • (c) Stomach – Involved in protein digestion and mixing food, but does not have villi

Additional Information:

  • Villi are lined with microvilli, further enhancing nutrient absorption.
  • The presence of villi makes the small intestine the main site of absorption in the human digestive system.

question:
In human beings, the small intestine is coiled and is about _______ metres long.

SSC MTS 12/07/2022 (1st shift)
solution:
• In human beings, the small intestine is a highly coiled, tubular structure responsible for digestion and absorption of nutrients.
  • It is approximately 7 to 7.5 meters long in adults.
  • The small intestine is divided into three parts:
    • Duodenum
    • Jejunum
    • Ileum
  • The length and coiled structure ensure a large surface area for maximum absorption of digested nutrients.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) 1 to 1.5 metres – much shorter than the actual length
    • (b) 3 to 3.5 metres – corresponds more to the length of the large intestine
    • (c) 2 to 2.5 metres – also shorter and incorrect

Additional Information:

  • The small intestine is lined with villi and microvilli, which further enhance its absorptive capacity.
  • It receives secretions from the liver (bile) and pancreas (enzymes) to complete digestion.

question:
Recommended dietary allowances (RDA) = ?

SSC MTS 15/07/2022 (1st shift)
option_1: Balanced diet – Extra nutrients
option_2: Requirements + Margin of safety
option_4: Intermittent fasting + Extra nutrients
solution:
• Recommended Dietary Allowances (RDA) refer to the average daily level of nutrient intake sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97–98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group.
  • It is calculated as:
    • RDA = Nutrient Requirements + Margin of Safety
  • The margin of safety accounts for:
    • Variability in individual needs
    • Environmental and physiological conditions
    • To ensure adequacy for almost everyone
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Balanced diet – Extra nutrients – This does not represent the RDA formula
    • (c) Extra nutrients – RDA is more than just extra nutrients; it is based on scientific estimation
    • (d) Intermittent fasting + Extra nutrients – Not related to the concept of RDA

Additional Information:

  • RDA values are issued by bodies like the ICMR (India), FDA, and WHO.
  • RDAs differ based on age, gender, activity level, and physiological conditions (like pregnancy, lactation).

question:
Which type of carbohydrate CANNOT be broken down by the GI tract, does not provide energy, but helps the body get rid of wastes and keeps the intestinal tract healthy?

SSC CHSL 27/05/2022 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Fibre.
  • Fibre is a type of complex carbohydrate that cannot be digested by the human gastrointestinal (GI) tract.
  • It does not provide energy, but plays a crucial role in:
    • Regulating bowel movements
    • Preventing constipation
    • Maintaining colon health
    • Removing waste and toxins from the body
  • Types of fibre:
    • Soluble fibre – dissolves in water (e.g., oats, fruits)
    • Insoluble fibre – adds bulk to stool (e.g., whole grains, vegetables)
  • Incorrect options:
    • (b) Starch – Digestible carbohydrate that provides energy
    • (c) Sugar – Simple carbohydrate; easily digested and gives quick energy
    • (d) Glycogen – Stored form of glucose in liver and muscles; provides energy when needed

Additional Information:

  • A diet high in fibre lowers the risk of heart disease, diabetes, and colon cancer.
  • Recommended intake: Around 25–30 grams of fibre per day for adults.

question:
Metabolic reactions in our body are carried out by:

SSC CHSL 31/05/2022 (1st shift)
solution:
• Metabolic reactions are the chemical processes that occur within a living organism to maintain life. These include digestion, respiration, synthesis of molecules, and breakdown of waste.
  • These reactions are primarily catalyzed and regulated by enzymes, which are biological catalysts.
  • Enzymes are made of proteins, hence proteins are responsible for carrying out metabolic reactions in the body.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (b) Carbohydrates – Provide energy but do not carry out reactions
    • (c) Lipids – Used for energy storage and membrane formation, not directly involved in catalyzing reactions
    • (d) Salts – Help maintain pH and ionic balance, but not directly involved in metabolic reactions

Additional Information:

  • Common examples of protein-based enzymes:
    • Amylase – breaks down starch
    • Lipase – breaks down fats
    • Pepsin – digests proteins
  • Without enzymes (proteins), metabolic reactions would occur too slowly to sustain life.

question:
________, a fluid secreted by new mothers during the initial days of lactation, contains nutrients that boost a baby’s immune system and helps fight infection.

SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)
solution:
• Colostrum is the first form of milk secreted by the mammary glands of mammals (including humans) immediately after giving birth.
  • It is a thick, yellowish fluid produced during the initial days of lactation.
  • Colostrum is rich in antibodies, especially IgA, and provides passive immunity to the newborn, helping protect against infections.
  • Key nutrients and components in colostrum:
    • Immunoglobulins (IgA, IgG)
    • White blood cells
    • Proteins, vitamins, and minerals
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Sebum – An oily substance secreted by sebaceous glands in the skin
    • (b) Synovia – A lubricating fluid in joints
    • (d) Cerumen – Also known as earwax, produced in the ear canal

Additional Information:

  • Colostrum is often referred to as “liquid gold” due to its immense nutritional and immune value.
  • It helps in developing the baby’s gut, making it ready for digestion and nutrient absorption.

question:
A large, muscular sheet called ________ forms the floor of the chest cavity.

SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (a) Diaphragm.
  • The diaphragm is a large, dome-shaped, muscular sheet that separates the chest cavity from the abdominal cavity.
  • It plays a key role in the process of breathing:
    • During inhalation, the diaphragm contracts and moves downward, increasing the volume of the chest cavity and allowing the lungs to expand.
    • During exhalation, it relaxes and moves upward, helping to push air out of the lungs.
  • Incorrect options:
    • (b) Larynx – Also called the voice box; located in the throat, not part of the chest floor
    • (c) Duodenum – The first part of the small intestine, located in the abdominal cavity
    • (d) Alveoli – Tiny air sacs in the lungs where gas exchange occurs; not a muscular structure

Additional Information:

  • The diaphragm is involuntary muscle, but some voluntary control is possible (e.g., during singing or holding breath).
  • Proper functioning of the diaphragm is essential for efficient respiration.

question:
Which of the following is the indigestible portion of our diet essential to the health of the digestive system?

SSC MTS 08/10/2021 (1st shift)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Roughage.
  • Roughage refers to the indigestible part of plant foods, also known as dietary fiber.
  • It is not digested or absorbed by the human digestive enzymes but plays a vital role in maintaining digestive health by:
    • Adding bulk to stool
    • Preventing constipation
    • Promoting regular bowel movements
    • Helping in removal of waste and toxins
  • Sources of roughage include:
    • Whole grains, fruits, vegetables, seeds, and legumes
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Fats – Provide energy; digestible
    • (c) Carbohydrates – Main source of energy; digestible
    • (d) Proteins – Help in body building and repair; digestible

Additional Information:

  • Roughage also helps in maintaining a healthy weight and reducing the risk of diabetes, heart disease, and colon cancer.
  • Recommended daily intake of dietary fiber: 25–30 grams for adults

question:
Complex food substances break down into simpler ones with the help of:

SSC MTS 27/10/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (b) Enzymes.
  • Enzymes are biological catalysts that speed up the breakdown of complex food substances into simpler, absorbable forms during digestion.
  • Each type of enzyme acts on a specific type of nutrient:
    • Amylase – breaks down carbohydrates (e.g., starch → maltose)
    • Protease (e.g., pepsin, trypsin) – breaks down proteins into amino acids
    • Lipase – breaks down fats into fatty acids and glycerol
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Hormones – Regulate processes but do not break down food
    • (c) Fungi – Involved in decomposition and fermentation, not direct digestion in humans
    • (d) Bacteria – Help in fermentation and producing vitamins in the gut, but the main breakdown of food is done by enzymes

Additional Information:

  • Most digestive enzymes are secreted by salivary glands, stomach, pancreas, and small intestine.
  • Without enzymes, digestion would be too slow to sustain life.

question:
Which of the following organs secretes hydrochloric acid that helps our body in killing pathogenic bacteria?

SSC CGL 16/08/2021 (Evening)
solution:
• The correct answer is (d) Stomach.
  • The stomach secretes hydrochloric acid (HCl) through its gastric glands.
  • Functions of HCl in digestion:
    • Kills pathogenic bacteria present in food
    • Activates pepsinogen into pepsin, an enzyme that digests proteins
    • Maintains an acidic pH (~1.5 to 3.5), which is essential for proper enzymatic activity in the stomach
  • Incorrect options:
    • (a) Brain – Controls body functions; does not secrete digestive substances
    • (b) Heart – Pumps blood; not involved in digestion
    • (c) Kidney – Filters blood and removes waste; unrelated to acid secretion

Additional Information:

  • Parietal cells in the stomach lining are responsible for the secretion of hydrochloric acid.
  • Excess HCl secretion can lead to acidity and ulcers.

question:
Which of the following reaction in human digestive system, is similar to the emulsification of soap upon the dirt?

RRB Group-D 17/08/2022 (Shift-II)
option_1: Spilitting of large fat granules in small granules by bile salts
option_2: Providing alkaline medium by bile juice
option_3: Assisting of starch digestion by bile juice enzymes
option_4: Providing acidic medium by the bile juice
solution:
• Emulsification is the process of breaking down large fat globules into smaller ones, increasing surface area for enzyme action.
  • In the human digestive system, bile salts (present in bile juice) play a key role in emulsifying fats.
  • This is similar to how soap breaks down grease/dirt into smaller droplets to wash them away—both involve emulsification.
  • Bile juice does not contain enzymes, so it does not directly digest starch or fats, but aids the process by emulsifying fats.

Additional Information:

  • Bile juice is produced by the liver and stored in the gallbladder.
  • It creates an alkaline medium in the small intestine but its primary mechanical function is fat emulsification.
  • The enzyme lipase then acts more efficiently on the smaller fat droplets.

question:
The site of complete digestion of carbohydrates, proteins and fat is:

RRB Group-D 17/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The small intestine is the primary site where the complete digestion of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats takes place.
  • Enzymes from the pancreas (like amylase, trypsin, and lipase) and from intestinal glands aid in breaking down all macronutrients.
  • Carbohydrates are broken down into glucose, proteins into amino acids, and fats into fatty acids and glycerol in the small intestine.
  • The duodenum, the first part of the small intestine, receives bile and pancreatic juice which are essential for digestion.

Additional Information:

  • Stomach partially digests proteins but not fats or carbohydrates fully.
  • Large intestine is mainly involved in water absorption, not digestion.
  • Rectum stores feces temporarily and plays no role in digestion.

question:
Which of the following is a balanced food in itself?

RRB Group-D 11/10/2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Milk is considered a complete or balanced food because it contains almost all essential nutrients required for the human body.
  • It provides proteins, fats, carbohydrates, vitamins (like A, D, B2) and minerals (like calcium and phosphorus).
  • Due to this comprehensive nutrient profile, milk supports growth, immunity, and bone health.

Additional Information:

  • Pulses are rich in proteins but lack some essential amino acids.
  • Meat is high in protein and iron but lacks dietary fiber and calcium.
  • Honey is mostly sugar (glucose + fructose) and lacks proteins, fats, and several vital vitamins/minerals.

question:
Which of the following enzymes in the saliva breaks down starch which is a complex molecule to give simple sugar?

RRB Group-D 17/09/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• The enzyme salivary amylase (also called ptyalin) is secreted by salivary glands.
  • It acts on starch, which is a complex carbohydrate, and breaks it down into maltose, a simple sugar.
  • This digestion begins right in the mouth during the process of chewing.
  • The optimal pH for salivary amylase activity is slightly alkaline or neutral (around pH 6.7–7.0).

Additional Information:

  • Salivary trypsin – incorrect, as trypsin digests proteins and is produced by the pancreas, not saliva.
  • Salivary lipase – digests fats, but it is not active in the mouth.
  • Salivary pepsin – pepsin is for protein digestion and is secreted in the stomach, not saliva.

question:
The ________ DOES NOT function as an excretory organ in humans.

RRB Group-D 18/08/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• The small intestine is responsible for digestion and nutrient absorption, not excretion.
  • It absorbs digested nutrients into the bloodstream but does not eliminate metabolic waste, so it is not considered an excretory organ.

Additional Information:

  • Lungs excrete carbon dioxide and water vapor during respiration.
  • Skin excretes sweat, which contains water, salts, and urea.
  • Large intestine helps in removal of undigested food and water absorption, and while not a primary excretory organ, it assists in elimination of solid waste.

question:
_________ aid (s) in the emulsification of fat.

RRB Group-D 18/08/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Bile salts, present in bile juice, play a key role in the emulsification of fats.
  • Emulsification is the process of breaking large fat globules into smaller droplets, which increases the surface area for lipase enzyme to act effectively.
  • This process occurs in the small intestine, particularly in the duodenum.

Additional Information:

  • Vitamin K is essential for blood clotting, not digestion.
  • Trypsin is a pancreatic enzyme that digests proteins, not fats.
  • HCl (hydrochloric acid) is present in the stomach and creates an acidic medium for pepsin, but does not emulsify fats.
  • Pepsin is a protein-digesting enzyme, active in the stomach, not involved in fat digestion.

question:
What is the rumen?

RRB Group-D 29/09/2022 (Shift-II)
option_1: The region of the gut where cud is formed
option_2: The first part of the duodenum of a cow
option_3: A chamber of the stomach to store food
option_4: A sac-like structure of the esophagus
solution:
• The rumen is the first and largest chamber of the stomach in ruminant animals like cows, buffaloes, goats, etc.
  • It serves as a storage chamber where partially chewed food (called cud) is stored and fermented by microbes.
  • In the rumen, symbiotic bacteria help in the breakdown of cellulose from plant material.
  • This food is later regurgitated as cud, chewed again, and passed to other stomach chambers for further digestion.

Additional Information:

  • Ruminants have a four-chambered stomach: Rumen, Reticulum, Omasum, and Abomasum.
  • The process of chewing cud is known as rumination.
  • The rumen plays a key role in microbial fermentation of food before true digestion.

question:
Which of the following organisms has a longer small intestine?

RRB Group-D 23/08/2022 (Shift-II)
solution:
• Cow, being a herbivore, has a longer small intestine compared to carnivores like tiger and lion, and even longer than that of humans.
  • Herbivores eat plant-based food, which contains cellulose—a complex carbohydrate that requires more time and surface area for digestion and absorption.
  • Hence, a longer small intestine allows for maximum nutrient absorption from fibrous plant material.

Additional Information:

  • Carnivores (like tiger and lion) have a shorter small intestine since meat is easier to digest.
  • Humans, being omnivores, have an intestine length between herbivores and carnivores.
  • The length of the small intestine is adapted to the dietary habits of the organism.

question:
In which part of the human body are villi present?

RRB Group-D 28/09/2022 (Shift-III)
solution:
• Villi are small, finger-like projections present on the inner walls of the small intestine.
  • Their main function is to increase the surface area for efficient absorption of nutrients from digested food.
  • Each villus contains a network of capillaries and a lacteal (lymph vessel) that help in the transport of absorbed nutrients into the bloodstream and lymph.

Additional Information:

  • Liver is a gland involved in bile production and metabolism, but it does not contain villi.
  • Kidneys filter blood and form urine; they have structures like nephrons, not villi.
  • Eyes are sensory organs with no role in digestion or absorption.

question:
An adult human being has only __________ incisors in his/her mouth.

RRB Group-D 06/10/2022 (Shift-I)
solution:
• An adult human has a total of 32 permanent teeth.
  • Out of these, there are 8 incisors:
    • 4 in the upper jaw (2 central + 2 lateral)
    • 4 in the lower jaw (2 central + 2 lateral)
  • Incisors are the front teeth used for cutting food.

Additional Information:

  • The full dental formula for an adult is:

    2 Incisors, 1 Canine, 2 Premolars, 3 Molars (per quadrant)

    So: (2+1+2+3) × 4 = 32 teeth

  • Other types of teeth:
    • Canines – 4
    • Premolars – 8
    • Molars – 12

question:
Match the columns.

RRB Group-D 26/09/2022 (Shift-II)

Group-I

Group-II

i. Mouth

A. Chewing of food

ii. Teeth

B. Rolling of food

iii. Tongue

C. Intake of whole food

iv. Saliva

D. Swallowing of food
option_1: I-A; II-D; III-A; IV-A
option_2: I-B; II-C; III-D; IV-C
option_3: I-A; II-B; III-C; IV-D
option_4: I-C; II-A; III-B; IV-D
solution:
Let's match each item in Group-I with the correct function from Group-II:

  • i. Mouth → C. Intake of whole food

    The mouth is the entry point where food is taken in.

  • ii. Teeth → A. Chewing of food

    Teeth break down food into smaller pieces through chewing (mastication).

  • iii. Tongue → B. Rolling of food

    The tongue moves and rolls the food into a bolus to aid swallowing.

  • iv. Saliva → D. Swallowing of food

    Saliva moistens food and contains enzymes, helping in swallowing and starting digestion.

Correct match:

  • i → C
  • ii → A
  • iii → B
  • iv → D

Answer: (d)
